column4: something autoloaded the file system ... how can I 'unbusy' it so I can run fsck?
what's the ubuntu equivalent of pmount?
what is pmount?
I was told to enter that to see if something had privately mounted the file system, since it is busy, but it's not a command
it is a waper arround mount
ah, ok. well, i have a catch 22.. fsck returns /dev/sda1 is busy or mounted. umount says not mounted. mount -t ext4 says nothing, but then still cannot umount
type mount
mount doesn't show it (or any ext4) mounted... just /dev/sr0 and dev/loop0 (running from an .iso as 'try' instead of 'install')
did you ever mount it or place it in fstab?

it had been mounted as my file system, then i had a hang. did the magic sysrq keys, and then every boot put me in grub. So i just booted from the livecd iso, selected "try ubuntu" rather than installing, and the file system shows in fdisk, but I cant get to it
this seems to be where I'm at...at the beginning of this post http://www.uluga.ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1682038
I dont think ubuntu auto-mounts stuff that is not in fstab, it could be seeign that it dected it but did not mount it but shows up under places area
the file system shows in the places pulldown...is that what's making it busy?
no ieda
do you want to keep dnome on system?
yes, I just want to try to prevent it from autoloading that file system so I can run fsck
well i can tell you the simple way or complex =P   simple: break x-server (this i have done a _LOT_ on axadent
so no keystroke to boot to cli or something? again, i'm booting from the .iso read-only, that said, how would I break X if that's the option?
http://www.linuxquestions.org/questions/linux-newbie-8/how-to-turn-off-xserver-in-the-gui-and-turn-it-off-in-the-command-line-219721/
yeah... i'm booting from a livecd to get at the old filesystem ... but gnome seems to have made it busy
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BootOptions
thanks :)
holding shift when it boots doesn't seem to bring up grub2
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BootOptions#Changing the CD's Default Boot Options
